ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned methods of fossilization and preservation, how to tell information from a fossil, and more about the history of life.
I learned that we are all fish.
I learned a lot about the evolution of life on earth and how to interpret fossils.
I learned a ton about fossils, taphonomy, and different ecosystems.

I improved my ability to look.  Reading and thinking about fossils and the creatures they came from was a wonderful way to spend my final semester.  I gained an appreciation for scale and our planetary existence.  It helped me not worry.

Lateral thinking and forming hypothesis. I think this class developed my creativity most of all. For a lot of the challenges in this class we had to use very little details to make guesses about what we were looking at.
I learned an incredible amount from this class. I admit that some of the knowledge is kind of niche, but it was all interesting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths were that the specimens were really interesting! It made the lecture course so much easier (and more enjoyable) to be able to see the fossils and how they exemplify whatever concepts we had in lecture that week. The TFs and professors were also a huge strength; they were usually really helpful when we got stuck. The collaborative aspect of this class was also great! Weaknesses were that the labs, questions, and instructions could be really confusing, especially in the first half of the class.

The course is nearly perfect. You learn so much in a welcoming environment, and Dr. Hull and Dr. Briggs are exceptional. The one weakness is that the labs assume more knowledge than could possibly be expected from the students. Some kind of pre-lab reading or lecture might help to clarify many of the confusing concepts we encounter in lab.
I think it is organized well for what it is.  The first few labs are a bit stressful, but you settle in well I think.

I wish this class had its own independent readings from the lecture. There were a lot of things we had to learn on the fly that it would have been nice to have some more explicit preparation in. For example if we had even had like a page of notes or little YouTube video on things like corals and echinoids I think the labs would have been much less stressful. Briggs would never give feedback on what he was counting off for but Hull was a very clear grader. This class SERIOUSLY reinforced the lectures. If you want an A in lecture take the lab.
Really really cool to be able to have access to so many of the Peabody's amazing specimen. But the questions asked in lab are often very hard to get without instructor help.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It was so interesting to see the fossils. The fossil evidence was so helpful for understanding concepts from the lecture and it was great getting to interact with the professors!
This course is great to take tangentially with the lecture since it makes those lectures much more manageable.
Yep! Absolutely! It's fun, you learn a lot, and it perfectly complements the material in lecture.
Absolutely. If you take the lecture, it would be helpful and fun to take this lab.  My best lab experience at Yale.

I would especially recommend this course to a student who is taking the lecture. If you are someone taking 125 as a science gut or you are an environmental studies major take the lab too and just credit/D it if you must. Especially on the midterm, this class was like an extra three hours of lecture study.
I would recommend this to anyone who is serious about learning from EPS 125. This lab helped me get so much more out of the regular course.

extras.title: EPS 126L 01 - Lab for the History of Life
